top_comment.text: The place is also freezing cold during the winter.﻿
top_comment.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
+Don Nguyen Dude, I'm not discussing extreme cold like the North Pole. I 
also know Canada is bad but not as bad as the South Pole or the North Pole, 
where you can freeze your ass to death. Cold is relative. But comparing the 
Northeast and the southern parts of the US, the southern states are better 
places to live.

That's fine if you want to live in a cold place like Canada. Some people 
are OK w/ it. However, most people aren't. In fact, there are almost 36 
million people in Canada. The US has about 320 million people. So something 
is wrong w/ Canada.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
I'm not saying I have a hate for hot places or sunny places.... I think SF 
is awesome, same with orange county, australia, and new zealand. Those are 
all places with sunny weather. It's only LA that i dont like because it's a 
train wreck rat race with too many people and dirty streets, thats all. All 
I'm saying is that me, along with many other people, like places that are 
simply clean and peaceful, and most of those places are colder.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
New York and other places in the east coast isn't "extreme cold", bro. You 
act like any place that has snow is like friggin Antarctica or something. 
There's a shit ton of people in NYC and Chicago who arent "miserable". 
Also, last time I checked, new york and ALL other places have this thing 
called summer. You act like nyc is some frozen wasteland all year round 
where people don't do shit.  But I'm done discussing it with you because 
you keep repeating the same point over and over again about hot places 
having a bigger population. You're obviously very stuck in your cali bubble 
so peace.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Don Nguyen I had lived in Thailand, the Philippines, and Cali. By far, 
southern Cali is the best state since it's not too hot or too cold. I did 
get a chance to live in New York but refused to move there due to the cold 
weather. According to research, it says people who live in extreme cold 
feel miserable b/c there are less things to do outside. Yes, New York State 
has about 19 million people, but Cali has about 38 million people. Also, 
Illinois has about 12 million people but Texas has almost 30 million 
people. This means you're in the minority. Most people believes it's better 
to live in warm or hot climate over cold climate. Even millions of illegal 
immigrants choose to live in the US. Canada should try to take all these 
immigrants to help its population growth.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
+Roy Long and just fyi, you do realise the main reason Canada has a small 
population is because 90% of the land is ice right?
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Roy Long I'm guessing you haven't lived anywhere else have you.. Typical 
californian spoiled and blinded by "nice weather". If you lived in a cold 
place and then decided on your preference, then you can talk. But it 
doesn't seem like you have, so you're stuck in this socal bubble where you 
live in all the hype and think that anywhere else besides cali sucks. I'm 
not saying you're wrong about many people wanting to live in sunny places, 
you're right about that. But I lived in both types of climates and I prefer 
cold places better. It's just my opinion, and you have yours. You forget 
that there's a zillion people living in NYC as well, and NYC is a cold 
place, yet it's the Biggest City in the US in terms of population, yet it's 
cold. How do you explain that? Also Chicago has over 10 million people as 
well.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Don Nguyen
Again, most people prefer living in warm or hot places. This is one of the 
main reasons people choose to live in the US than to live in Canada. Most 
people don't want to live in a cold place where there isn't much things to 
do during the winter. In other words, you would feel trapped indoors and 
feel miserable during the bitter cold. Plus, the terms "a lot" is too 
general.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
+Roy Long You keep mentioning places and population and maybe you should 
listen better. A LOT of people DON'T WANT a big population. Jesus.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Don Nguyen No, that's not the point. We're only discussing about North 
America. Keep in mind that Alaska is the biggest state in the US. However, 
most people live in warm states such as Cali and Texas. It's too cold to 
live in Alaska, which is right next to Canada.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
+Roy Long So basically just because there's people in california that means 
everyone should just live there right? So I guess everyone should just go 
ahead and move to India because there's so many people. Thanks but no 
thanks, I will go somewhere cold and have my balls shrink and be happy.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Don Nguyen
When the weather is too cold, it makes your dick shrink....ha ha ha

In case you don't know, Canada is bigger than the US, and California is 
much smaller than than Canada. However, there are more people living in 
California than Canada. Why? It's cold and miserable. That's why most 
people don't want to live there. It's suck!

Even in America, there are less people living  in cold states than warm/hot 
states. So the main reason that the LA areas are crowed is due to supply 
and demand. It's basic economics. When the demand is high, things and 
resources can get scarce, causing prices and expenses to go high.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
cities in the world for best quality of life: none in the US.
cities in the US for best quality of life: none of them are LA.
You can't honestly say that just because LA has "famous" places or "famous" 
people or "good weather" that it's anything near a good city to live. So 
what if it has a big population, doesn't mean anything. China and India 
have the biggest populations in the world.. does that mean India is the 
best place to be? No. That high population that people think they looove so 
much about LA and the whole socal area in fact is what causes the 
neverending traffic, smog, pollution, cracked and shitty highways, dirty 
streets, expensive cost of living, and over-crowded places. And don't even 
get me started on the crime in LA. The point is that people think just 
because it has sunny weather blah blah blah that's it's such a nice place, 
when it's not. Good weather is a matter of perception. Someone can love 
cloudy and cold weather and be perfectly happy in a place that has 4 
distinct seasons. California doesn't have seasons, but like I said, it 
depends on the person. So if you love California so much because of the 
lack of seasons weather and its "famous" people who you will never meet or 
be affected by, then good for you. But there is no denying that places like 
LA have a long list of problems that aren't worth dealing with just for 
sunny weather.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Roy Long
LA is a shit city covered in smog, sluts, and broken dreams. Good weather 
isn't worth it. Only pussies can't handle cold weather.
comments.author: Saul Goodman

comments.text:
+Dramus II
It does have Indians.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text: +Roy Long And Canada don't have mexicans
comments.author: Dramus II

comments.text:
+ryan ball

But most of the world population live in large cities due to jobs and sex 
partners. Toronto and New York City are large cities.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text: +Roy Long Most people want less people around them not more people. Ugh.
comments.author: ryan ball

comments.text:
+ofelixdacat The temperatures are relative. In Long Beach, the temperatures 
are about 80-90 deg F during the summer. Huntington Beach is one of the 
coolest cities in CA. So the temps are much cooler near the beaches. But 
the average temps in Riverside county are 100-110 deg F; it's much hotter 
than LA.
comments.author: Roy Long

comments.text:
+Roy Long  No not at all, it's hot all over California. It is 100+ degrees 
today in LA. I live in California I should know, plus it shows in the 
Mountains here and it can be freezing cold here too.
comments.author: B!tch-U-Out

comments.text:
+Jeremiah Basa
Wrong! It's only hot in the desert parts of California, where most people 
don't live there.
comments.author: Roy Long

captions.text:
Canada's capital is located in a valley along
the Ottawa River in the province of Ontario,
close to the American border.
Ottawa is the country's fourth-largest city

and attracts more than 7 million visitors
each year.

Come to Ottawa to celebrate its quality of
life,

to explore its waterways and to enjoy its
many cultural attractions.

This modern centre for technology and science
still has a deep appreciation for ceremony
and history.
Often thought of as a winter destination,

this city comes to life during the warmer
months when locals enjoy the pop-up terraces
on the waterfront

and have outdoor meals in culinary districts
such as Little Italy.

Go for a walk or a bike ride to explore the
downtown area
and follow the pathways along the Rideau Canal.

It cuts the city in two and gradually makes
its way down to the Ottawa River.

The 1827 Commissariat Building, now the Bytown
Museum, is where Ottawa began.

It was built as the depot for the British
engineers who set out to construct the Ottawa
locks,
under the supervision of colonel John By.

Bytown became Ottawa in 1855 and was made
the seat of government soon after.

Come to Parliament Hill in summer to see the
Changing of the Guard Ceremony

when the clock of the Peace Tower strikes
ten.
It's a spectacle not to be missed!

Cross the locks to see the National Gallery
of Canada.

Its exterior reflects the sky and its inner
courts embrace nature.

The gallery's exhibits paint the story of
Canada's past.
Walk over to the nearby Notre Dame Basilica

to take in its 19th-century Gothic Revival
facade and ornate interior.

A few blocks away, the ByWard Market is THE
place to go for lunch,
with its good selection of mouthwatering treats.

Don't worry; the advertised beavertails are
just a deep-fried pastry.
Also try some of the delicious fruit,
which comes straight from the farms in Quebec.

The Canada Agriculture and Food Museum is
the living proof
that this Green City loves fresh produce.

Learn about growing your own food, meet the
animals

and check out the machinery in this working
farm in the heart of the city.

The sky is the limit in the Canada Aviation
And Space Museum,

an airport hangar filled with vintage planes
and modern spacecraft.

Across the water in Quebec is the marvelous
Canadian Museum of Civilization.

Step back in time in this recreation of Canada's
past

to explore log cabins, shops and vehicles
from a bygone time.

Not far from the museum is the start of the
huge conservation area called Gatineau Park.

After some close encounters in the visitor
centre,

hike to picturesque lakes and enjoy a few
hours on the beach.

Before you leave the park, have lunch in the
Tearoom of the MacKenzie King Estate,

the historic summer retreat of Canada's longest
serving prime minister.
As the second-largest country in the world,

Canada has everything from snowcapped mountains
to lush valleys

and more wilderness than you can explore in
a lifetime.

And as the capital of all of this, Ottawa
offers just a taste of what is to come.
